title: RS22607
content: It is a federal crime to assault, kidnap, or kill a federal judge or their family members with the intent to obstruct or retaliate for the judge's duties. The penalties are increased for such offenses, including voluntary manslaughter up to 15 years and involuntary manslaughter up to 8 years. Other federal statutes also adopt similar penalty structures. Section 207 of P.L. 110-177 increases penalties for manslaughter, extending to federal judges, officers, and witnesses. The amendment also covers murder, assaults, and threats to influence or retaliate against witnesses in federal proceedings. Assaults and threats to influence or retaliate against witnesses in federal proceedings are subject to increased penalties under P.L. 110-177. The penalties for witness tampering or retaliation involving physical force have been raised to a maximum of 30 years, while those involving the threat of force have been increased to 20 years. Additionally, harassment now carries a penalty of up to 3 years. Section 204 of the law allows for prosecution of witness retaliation offenses in either the location of the violation or where the proceeding occurred, although this may raise constitutional concerns.
